lg.l: The Modern Dame is wak'd by noon,
Some Authors say not quite so soon;
Because though sore againts her will,
She sat all night up at Quadrill.
She stretches, gapes, unglues her Eyes,
And asks if it be time to Rise:
Of head·ach, & ye spleen complains:
And then to cool her heated brains,
Her night-gown & her slippers brought her
Takes a Large dram of Citron water.
Then to her glass; & Betty, pray
Don't I look frightfully to Day?
But was it not confounded hard,
Well, if I ever touch a card?
Four Mattadores, & lose codill
Depend upon't, I never will!
But run to Tom, & bid him fix
The Ladies here to night at six
Madṃ the Gold-smith waits below,
He says his business is to know,
If you'll redeem the silver cup,
You pawn'd him; first shew him up.
Your dressing-plate, he'll be content
To take for intrest cent per cent.
And Madm, there's my Lady Spade
Hath sent this Letter by her maid.
Well, I remember what she won?
And hath she sent so soon to dun?
Here, carry down those ten Pistoles,
My Husband left to pay for coals.
I thank my stars, they are all light;
And I may have revenge to night.
Now, loitering ore her Tea and Cream,
She enters on her usual Theme;
Her last nights ill success repeats,
Calls Lady spade a hundred cheats:
She slipt Spadillo in her breast,
Then thought to turn it to a jest.
There's, Mrs Cutt, and she combine
And to each other give the Signe,
Through ev'ry game pursue her tale,
Like Hunters o're their Evening Ale.
Now to another sceen give place,
Enter the folks with silk & lace:
Fresh matter for a world of chat,
Right indian this, right mackling that.
Observe this pattern; there's, a stuff,
I can have customers enough.
Dear Madm, you are grown so hard
This lace is worth twelve pounds a yard
Madm. if there be truth in man,
I never sold so cheap a fan.
This business of importance o'er,
And Madm almost dresst by four;
The foot-man in his usial phrase
Comes up, with Madm, dinner stays.
She answers in her usual style,
The cook must keep it back a while.
I never can have time to dress
No woman breathing takes up less
I'm, hurred so, it makes me sick,
I wish ye dinner at old Nick.
At Table now she acts her part,
Has all ye dinner-cant by heart,
I thought we were to dine alone,
My Dear, for sure if I had known
This company would come to Day,
But really tis my Spouses way.
He's so unkind he never sends
To tell, when he invites his freinds:
I wish we may but have enough!
And while with all this paultry stuff
Sits tormenting every guest,
Nor gives her tongue one moments rest,
In phrases batter'd stale & trite,
Which modern Ladies call polite;
You see ye Booby Husband sit,
In admiration at her wit.
But let me now a while survey
Our Madm, o'er her Evening-tea;
Surrounded with her noisy clans
Of prudes, coquets, & harridans;
When frighted, at ye clamorous crew,
Away ye God of silence flew,
And fair discretion left ye place,
And modesty with blushing face,
Now enters over-weening pride,
And scandal ever gaping wide,
Hypocrisy with frown severe,
Scurrility with gibon'r air;
Rude laughter seeming like to burst
And malice always judging worst;
And vanity with pocket-glass
And impudence with front of Brass:
And studed affectation came,
Each limb, & feature out of frame;
While ignorance with brain of lead,
Flew hovering o'er each female head.
Why should I ask of ye my muse
An hundred tongues, as poets use,
When to give ev'ry Dame her due,
An hundred thousand were to few:
Or how should I alass, relate
The sum of all their senseless prate
Their innuendo's hints & slanders
Their meaning lewd, & double entandre's
Now comes ye general slander charge
What some invent, ye rest inlarge;
And, Madm, if it be a lye,
You have ye tale as cheap as I:
I must conceal my Authors name,
But now tis known to common fame.
Say foolish female, old & blind:
Say by what fatal turn of mind
Are you on vices most severe
Where·in, your selves have greatest share
Thus every fool her self deludes,
The prudes condemn the absent prudes.
Mopsa who stinks her spouse to death,
Accuse's chloe's tainted breath
Hireian rank with sweat presumes
To censure Phillis for perfumes:
While crooked Cynthia swearing says,
That Florimel wears jorn stays.
Chloe of every coxcomb jealous,
Admires how girls can talk with fellows.
And full of indignation frets
That Women should be such coquets.
Iris, for slander most notorious,
Cries, Lord, ye world is so censorious
And Bufa with her combs of lead
Wispers that Sappho's hair is red.
Aura, whose tongue can hear a mile hence
Talks half a Day in praise of silence:
And silvia full of inward guilt,
Calls Amoret an arrant jilt.
Now voices over voices rise
While each to be ye loudest vies,
They contradict, affirm, dispute,
No single tongue one moment mute:
All Mad to speak, and none to hearken
They set the very Lap-dog barking;
Their Chattering makes a louder din
Then Fish-wives o'er a cup of Gin.
Not school-boys at a barring out,
Rais'd ever such incessant rout
The slumbering particles of Matter
In Chaos makes not such a clatter.
Far less the rabble roar, & rail,
When drunk sour Election Ale.
Nor, do they trust their tongues a·lone,
To speak a langauge of their own:
Can read a nod, a shrug, a look,
Much better then a printed book:
Convey a libel in a frown,
And wink a reputation down;
Or by ye tossing of ye Fan,
Describe ye Lady & ye man.
But, see ye female club disbands,
Each, twenty visits on her hands.
Now all alone poor Madm Sits,
In vapours & Histerick fits:
And was not Tom this morning sent,
I'd lay my life he never went.
Past Six, & not aliving soul?
I might by this have won a vole.
A dreadful interval of spleen!
How shall we pass ye time between.
Here Betty, let me take my drops,
And feel my pulse, I know it stops:
This head of mine, Lord how it swims!
And such a pain in all my Limbs.
Dear Madm try to take a nap,
But now they hear a Foot-mans rap,
Go run & light ye Ladies up:
It must be one before we sup.
The table, Cards, & counters set,
And all ye Gamesters, Ladies met,
Her spleen & fits recoverd quite,
Our Madm can sit up all night.
Who ever comes I'm not within,
Quadrill ye word & so begin.
How can ye muse her Aid impart
Unskill'd in all ye terms of Art?
Or in harmonious numbers put
The deal, ye shuffle, & ye cut!
The superfluous whims relate,
That fill a female gamester's pate:
What agony of soul she feels
To see a knave's inverted heels:
She draws up card, by card to find
Good fortune peeping from be·hind.
With panting heart & earnest eyes,
In hopes to see Spadillo rise;
In vain alass her hope is fed;
She draws an Ace, & sees it Red.
In ready counters never pays,
But pawns her snuff-box rings & keys.
Ever with some new fancy struck
Tries twenty charms to mend her luck
This morning when the parson came,
I said I should not win a game,
This odious chair how came I stuck in't?
I think I never had good luck in't.
I'm so uneasy in my stays;
Your Fan, a moment if you please
Stand further girl, or git you gon
I all·ways lose when you look on.
Lord Madm, you have lost Codill;
I never saw you play so ill:
Nay Madm give me leave to say,
T'was you that threw the game a way:
When Lady Tricksy playd a four
You took it with a Mattadore,
I saw you touch your wedding ring,
Before my Lady call'd a King,
You spoke a word begun with H,
And I know who you meant to teach
Because you held ye King of Hearts
Fy Madm, leave these little arts.
Thats not so bad as one that rubs
Her chair to call the King of Clubs.
And makes her partner understand,
A matadore is in her hand.
Madm you have no cause to flounce,
I swear I saw you twice renounce.
And truly Madm I know when,
In·stead of five you scoard up ten.
Spadillo here has got a mark,
A Child may know it in ye dark:
I guess ye hand it seldom fails,
I wish some folk's would pare there nails
While thus they rail and scold & storm
It passes but for common form
And conscious that they all speak true,
And give each other but their due
It never interrupts ye game,
Or makes, them sensible of shame.
The time to precious now to waste,
The supper gobbling up in haste.
A·gain a·fresh to cards they run,
As if they had but, just begun:
Yet I shall not a·gain repeat
How oft they squable snort and cheat;
At last they hear the watch-man knock
A frosty morn──past four a clock
The Chair·men are not to be found
Come, Let us play another round
Now all in haste they huddle on,
Their hoods, their clokes, & get them gone:
But first the winners must invite
The company to morrow night.
Unlucky Madm, left in fears,
Who now a·gain Quadrill for·swears,
With empty purse & aching head,
Steals to her Sleeping spouse to bed.444-902A
